Overall, the new UI design is great! However, the text hierarchy I'm currently seeing on the "Create New World" screen makes everything look like it's all the same level. In other words, the "Gameplay" section title should use a larger font than the option titles below it, or perhaps all caps like the "CREATE" button. Same for "Add-on Creators", etc. This alone would improve UX. I also would be a huge fan of having the toggle buttons on the left rather than on the far right side. Seems like having the toggles closer to the option titles and main menu sidebar would be a quicker visual read. One thing that kinda drives me nuts is the screen hopping that takes place when you click on a "Difficulty" setting, or other button option, due to the descriptive text not having the same number of lines for each. This could be solved by just forcing the description space to always be as large as the option with the most text. Again, everything looks great. Just pointing out some things that could improve it. Thanks, Mojang!!!

Look, I know most people will disagree but hear me out. I don't think enough has changed. This seems like the same things just rearranged a little. When I saw that preview from 2018, or whenever it was, it looked amazing. Now it seems like just a reskin of the old UI, which sucks on consoles. I also thought maybe some inspiration would be taken from other versions. The Legacy console editions perfected the UI. And while I don't think that UI would work in this case, you could learn something from how it was done. I do appriciate the explanations for certain toggles. It will be a big help to new players. But I honestly think that the first UI concept from a few years ago is better overall. It made the game seem more professional, like the multi-platform bestselling game that it is. I really hope that what was done here isn't final. I think more needs to be changed, especially with performance on consoles. Edit: one suggestion I do have is to put the toggle switches on the left of the text. It's much harder to press with a mouse when it's on the right.

The redesign of the new create world UI looks great so far. But here is what I believe it could make better on pc/touch controls.

1. On (windows 10/11) under general, I feel that the new create world UI is a bit too big and takes too much space into the screen. For the game mode and difficulty. My solution for this problem would be to make the buttons similar to Minecraft Java UI. By making one button for the game mode and one button for difficulty. You can click or if you are on touch controls you can tap, go to the next game mode/difficulties. It would save up some space and make it cleaner. Instead of having a button for each game mode and difficulty.   

2. Under general it needs more content in it. There are only 3 options. World name, game mode and difficulty. To fix this you can move 2 buttons from the advanced tab. Which are world seed and flat world. Move it to the general tab because having all world options under one tab makes it cleaner. Also, I feel that the advance tab has too much content in it. By moving these 2 options it looks less congested.

Critique and suggestion,
1. New world basic tab elements: Please include these elements, world seed, starter map, bonus chest, and show coordinates. These are elements that are basic, I use them every single world no matter how casual and I've never considered them as advanced options, most especially the world seed. These are also the options most beneficial and likely (I'd expect anyway) to be used by casual and new players, especially the world seed which many are likely to find specific seeds they want to try from various media sources.
2. Game Type and Difficulty. This one is more opinion, but I much prefer dropdown boxes than the radial buttons you have in the new look. Radial buttons take up more space which feels like you are just straining to fill the screen. More than that, a dropdown box puts greater focus and clarity on the selected choice rather than the selection of possible options, which, in the case of difficulty and world type, should be focused on the selected choice over possible options.
3. Scaling. A huge thing with most mobile friendly programs these days, but please make scaling more flexible. Having a tablet or even my laptop (with android x86, yet to be tested but on my todo list), the screen is far too big for a button 1/3 the screen length to be comforable. I suggest making the scale a user adjustable variable, so a big screen even if low res, can have smaller elements. Definitely should not be based on system type nor resolution.
End part 1.

Part 2, critique and suggestion.
4. Descriptive text. I like this addition, but some of them aren't really helpful and need rewriting.
5. Visual aesthetics. Amazing job on this aspect. Good color distinction and yet very minimal and clear.
6. World seed. This should be presented in blocks of 3-5 digits, to make them easier to share and type with less error. At least when in numerical format. I personally use words and let them get converted. Easier to remember even more than a big number, so randomly provided seeds can be words or phrases to make them easier to remember and share. And if an alphanumeric string, like words and phrases or even leet, then having that string remembered as the world's seed and thus returned as the world's seed even though the string is converted before use, as it is much easier to share "TheBeginning" as a seed than "-1682425972".

I agree that in-game single player pausing is a very necessary quality of life/accessibility/flexibility feature that must be present in Minecraft Bedrock, and that is only standard to games of this nature. I recommend this feature work when the "Multiplayer Game" option is disabled (or LAN is disabled), to remove any confusion from the game when it comes to distinguishing between single-player and multiplayer settings. Then, I also recommend making the "Multiplayer Game" option disabled by default, to avoid confusion among players when it comes to pausing their game in single player mode.

I hope that this could be presented as a one time option for the up coming 1.6 update. I imagine it working as follows:

When entering a nether dimension that was previously loaded in any version before 1.6, The player will be asked "Would you like to reset this world's Nether Dimension? Doing so will erase the entire dimension and replace it with a new one." [Yes] and [No] buttons will appear below. If [No] is selected, the player will be asked if they are sure and that they will not have another chance to reset their game (unless they edit the game files). [Back] and [Don't Reset] buttons will appear below. Selecting [Back] returns the player to the previous question. Selecting [Don't Reset] leaves the Nether alone and the player is never again offered the choice to reset their Nether. If [Yes] was selected for the first question, the player will be warned that doing so will remove anything they have built in the nether. [Back] and [Reset Nether] buttons will appear below. Selecting [Reset Nether] will delete the world's files for the nether and create new ones and the player will never be offered the choice again.

It has actually been possible to do this since Android 4. I've used apps that do it on Android 5 and 7. It's not exactly obvious how in older versions but it is only a few lines of code. The main trick is you need to trap the KeyPress and Motion events and use GetSource to test if it's a mouse before deciding whether you want to handle the events. Handling the key event is necessary for certain vendors like Samsung that remap the middle and right buttons to home and back. There's two separate motion event types that you have to handle depending on whether or not a button is pressed as well. The trick to simulating capture is to use the accessibility service to move the mouse pointer back to the center of the screen every time it moves. Hiding the pointer is a good idea when you do that but I believe you can only hide it in Android 7 and up.

Is this the excuse for making it incompatible with Chromebooks? Makes sense, because with the mouse settings displayed in the menu, you can argue that it is broken and the experience is inconsistent.

Problem is that there is an incentive NOT to fix this. Microsoft has already lost or is losing the market to the next generation (i.e. school kids), whom overwhelmingly use Chromebooks. This is probably why Education Edition on Chromebooks REQUIRES a school-based Microsoft account (which is rare for most districts/localities compared to a school-based Google account). IF Microsoft fixes this issue, they'll have a harder time defending making it incompatible with Chromebooks, and people would just figure out to sideload it anyway (I have). If it is compatible with Chromebooks, that is one more piece of leverage they lose in the fight to win back the next generation to the Microsoft ecosystem.

Here is another thought.

IF they fix this on Android/Chromebooks, it essentially becomes equivalent to the Windows 10 version, but $20 cheaper! People who paid $27 for the Windows 10 version, but would have otherwise used the Android/Chromebook version would scream bloody murder.

They could also raise the price on Android to make it the same as the Windows 10 and console version, but people would scream bloody murder about that.

They could make a SEPARATE Android version, only for Chromebooks, that costs the same as Windows 10 ($27), but people would scream bloody murder again because the only difference would be mouse support, for which there is clearly no technical barrier.

If this is what is really going on, they are really stuck. The problem is that the pricing of Android apps is so different (i.e. cheaper) than other platforms, it is really hard to make things fair for both the consumer AND Microsoft in terms of value.

So, how about a paid $20 upgrade option (e.g. in-app purchase) for the Android version that adds/unlocks mouse support? People using phones and tablets can still be happy with the base $7 option, and people like me would much rather fork over an extra $20 vs. all kinds of crazy workarounds like Crostini, Java etc. It's not a GREAT option, but it seems to be the most fair to me. Maybe there are business/technical/legal reasons why they can't do something like this.

Shut up and take my money! 😉

Also, while they might be able to work something out on Android/Chromebook with respect to a different version or in-app-purchase to unlock mouse support, that might be more difficult to do with Apple devices due to their more restrictive policies (e.g. see the current fight between Epic and Apple over Fortnite).
